statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Mississippi 73, Arkansas 70
article.story: OXFORD, Miss. (AP) -- Mississippi needed a big game from a key senior to stop a pesky slide -- and perhaps turn a streaky season back around. Londrick Nolen scored 20 points to help Ole Miss snap a seven-game losing streak with a 73-70 win over Arkansas on Wednesday night. "This team deserved to win some games," Rebels coach Rod Barnes said. "There are too many games left for us to lock up. It was just a matter of relaxing and playing. This is a good team, and I thought we really came together tonight." Bam Doyne gave Ole Miss a three-point lead when he made a free throw with 9 seconds left. The Razorbacks had one last chance to force overtime, but Jonathon Modica missed a 3-pointer with 3 seconds remaining. "We made too many mistakes at the end of the game, a lot of them mental mistakes," Arkansas coach Stan Heath said. "I'm disappointed with the loss. I'm disappointed with the way we played. We haven't played that way this year." Dwayne Curtis had 19 points and 13 rebounds for the Rebels (14-10, 4-7 Southeastern Conference), whose seven-game slide followed a seven-game winning streak. They won for the first time since their 75-65 victory over rival Mississippi State on Jan. 14 capped a 3-0 start to the SEC schedule. "It was a relief," Nolen said of ending the slide. "There was some joy, too. But, it was definitely a relief." Nolen, a senior who is winding down his college career, was 8-of-11 shooting with eight rebounds and three assists. "I told Londrick that these last eight games would be the best of his career, so I'm not surprised," Barnes said. Ronnie Brewer and Modica had 16 points apiece to lead Arkansas (16-8, 5-6), and Eric Ferguson added 15 points. The Razorbacks have lost five conference road games by a combined 11 points, including their last three away from Fayetteville by a combined six points. Ole Miss shot better than 46 percent, outrebounded Arkansas 43-37 and held the Razorbacks to less than 40 percent shooting. "Ole Miss played the way we should have played," Heath said. "They sped us up. They were a team that had lost seven straight, and they played like this was for the top of the league. They had a lot of fire and we didn't." Arkansas led 42-37 with less than 17 minutes to play before Ole Miss rallied. Nolen's tip-in with 15:39 to play came during an 8-0 run and gave the Rebels the lead for good. "He can do that at any time, and he's tough when he gets it going," Curtis said of Nolen. Ole Miss led by as many as nine with 2:28 remaining, but poor free-throw shooting allowed Arkansas to make a late push. The Rebels missed five foul shots down the stretch. Arkansas pulled to 71-70 when Vincent Hunter put back an offensive rebound with 13 seconds to play.
